title-group.article-title: Mid-term Periodicity of Coronal Mass Ejections during the Time Interval 1996–2022

contrib-group.aff: 1 Center for Astrophysics and Great Bay Center of National Astronomical Data Center, Guangzhou University, Guangzhou 510006, People's Republic of China; denghui@gzhu.edu.cn, meiying@gzhu.edu.cn, fengwang@gzhu.edu.cn
2 Peng Cheng Laboratory, Shenzhen 518000, People's Republic of China

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Coronal mass ejections (CMEs) exhibit a wide range of quasiperiodic variations and are crucial for our understanding of the cyclical evolution of large-scale magnetic fields. However, the mid-term periodicities of different types of CMEs associated with different processes at the source location need to be clearly understood. Based on the CDAW catalog released by the Large Angle and Spectroscopic Coronagraph mission on the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory, we investigated the period of CMEs based on the speeds and accelerations using the continuous wavelet transformation method. Our results revealed that the distribution of CMEs over time is quite distinctly different for different speeds, and there are Rieger-type periods and quasi-biennial oscillations of the CMEs. The two types of periodic signals show significant differences in solar cycles 23 and 24. Furthermore, the periodicity patterns for the northern hemisphere differ from those in the southern hemisphere. The potential mechanisms and explanations of the results are also discussed.

award-group.funding-source: the National SKA Program of China, Guangzhou Science
the National Natural Science Foundation of China
the Major Key Project of Peng Cheng Laboratory, Basic and Applied Basic Research Foundation Project of Guangdong Province
the “Yunnan Revitalization Talent Support Program” Innovation Team Project, the Yunnan Fundamental Research Projects

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Coronal mass ejections (CMEs) are the spectacular eruptive phenomena of the Sun, first detected in 1971 by the OSO-7 coronagraph (Tousey 1973). CMEs play an important role in solar physics and the space weather (Gopalswamy et al. 2000, 2022; Wang et al. 2002; Chen 2011; Webb & Howard 2012). Numerous high-quality CME observations have been obtained thanks to the Large Angle and Spectrometric Coronagraph (LASCO; Brueckner et al. 1995) on board the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) mission (Domingo et al. 1995). There have been conducted studies on the characteristics of CMEs, such as the detection rates (Michalek et al. 2019; Bilenko 2020), the mass rates (Vourlidas et al. 2010; Mishra et al. 2019; Michalek et al. 2022), the angular widths (Yashiro et al. 2004), latitudes (Lin et al. 2022), and the speeds (Yashiro et al. 2004; Lara et al. 2006).

The various periodicities of solar magnetic fields have a profound impact on the conditions of space weather. The classical period of solar magnetic activity is the Schwabe Cycle (Schwabe 1844), later known as the solar cycle. Apart from the solar cycle, the Sun also exhibits other quasiperiodic variations like the Rieger-type periodicities (Rieger et al. 1984) and quasi-biennial oscillations (Bazilevskaya et al. 2014), which can be categorized as the mid-term periodicity (Inceoglu & Loto’aniu 2023). Rieger et al. (1984) initially noted the 154 day periodicity in the gamma-ray flare activity in the 1980s, known as the Rieger-periods, later the 152–158 days of the rate of occurrence of hard X-ray and gamma-ray flares were reviewed by Dennis (1985). In addition, a 154 day periodicity is also found in the other activity Hα flare activity (Ichimoto et al. 1985), the occurrence rate of solar flares (Bai & Cliver 1990; Droege et al. 1990), sunspot areas (Carbonell & Ballester 1990), 10.7 cm flux (Kile & Cliver 1991) and coronal Fe xiv emission at 530.3 nm (Kotzé 2023), microwave peak flux (Bogart & Bai 1985), and so on. Bai & Sturrock (1991) suggested that the periodic of 154 days is the subharmonics of the fundamental period of 25 days based on the flare and sunspot records, and Bai & Sturrock (1993) gave a similar result after investigating the longitude distributions of major flares. Meanwhile, Krivova & Solanki (2002) suggested that the power at the 156 ± 2 days of solar flares is seen to fluctuate roughly in phase with the 1.28 yr period (quasi-biennial oscillations), and proposed that the Rieger period is the third harmonic of the 1.3 yr period. Based on the helioseismic probing of the Sun’s interior, Howe et al. (2000) suggested that the 1.3 yr is roughly equal to a varied period in the rotation rate near the base of the Sun’s convection zone. Meanwhile, Lou (2000) pointed out that the periods of 153 ± 2, 126.5 ± 0.5, 101.5 ± 0.5, 77 ± 1, and 52.5 ± 1.5 days could be examined by Rossby and mixed Rossby–Poincaré waves, and emphasized that it would be interesting to investigate whether similar periodicities are also present in large-scale CMEs.

The mid-term quasiperiodicity of CMEs has been covered before by Lou et al. (2003) only using the data from 1999 February 5 to 2003 February 10; they identified the periods of 358 ± 38, 272 ± 26, 196 ± 13 days, and so forth of the daily numbers of CMEs. They also examined the mid-term quasiperiodicities of the class >M 5.0 solar flares and the Ap index (which is an index for the geomagnetic disturbances); they suggested the significant periodic signal at 273 ± 26 and 187 ± 12 days could imply that CMEs might be proportionally correlated with quasiperiodic geomagnetic storm disturbances, and meanwhile speculated that the class >M 5.0 flares drive certain types of geomagnetic disturbances. Further, Kilcik et al. (2020) evaluated the periodic variations between the maximum CME speed index and the numbers of different class flares, and they suggested that generally, the two series exhibit similar periodic behavior, but rather that the 546 day periodicity (quasi-biennial oscillations) found in the maximum CME speed index may not be solar-originated, or at least not caused by solar flares.

The quasi-biennial oscillations are known as a global phenomenon extending from the subsurface layers of the Sun to Earth and throughout the heliosphere. Their physical source could potentially be connected to the dynamical mechanism in solar tachocline (Zaqarashvili et al. 2010; Kiss & Erdélyi 2018). Inceoglu & Loto’aniu (2023) detected solar quasi-biennial oscillation-like signals in Earth’s magnetic field from multiple Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite missions. Typically, the CME speed index could be a helpful evaluation of solar and geomagnetic activity (Kilcik et al. 2011). The speeds of CMEs associated with flares are faster than the ones associated with eruptive prominences (Gosling et al. 1976). Yashiro et al. (2004) suggested that a large number of fast CMEs (V > 900 km s−1) exhibit deceleration, while a large number of slow (V ≤ 250 km s−1) CMEs exhibit acceleration. Meanwhile, Du (2021) found that the correlation between CME acceleration and sunspot activity in solar cycle 24 is weaker than that in solar cycle 23, and the average CME acceleration over the weaker sunspot activity cycle 24 is much larger than that in the stronger sunspot activity cycle 23. Gopalswamy et al. (2014) pointed out that there is a correlation between CME speeds and widths, and the slope of speeds and widths for solar cycle 23 is 0.11 while solar cycle 24 is 0.16, indicating that for a given CME speed, the CME width in the cycle 24 is wider. Additionally, Li et al. (2023) carefully investigated the quasiperiodic variations of CME widths and showed that quasiperiodic variations for CMEs are important factors among oscillations in coronal magnetic activity, solar flare eruptions, and interplanetary space.

Thus, we devoted detailed investigations of the mid-term periodicity of CMEs in this paper. The data and method will be given in the next section, and then the analyses and results will be presented in the following section. Finally, it comes to the conclusion and discussions of the last section.

sec.title: Data
sec.p:
The most commonly used catalog for CME studies is the Coordinated Data Analysis Workshop catalog 5
5
https://cdaw.gsfc.nasa.gov/CME_list (CDAW; Gopalswamy et al. 2009b; Michalek et al. 2019). The CDAW catalog includes information on the center position angle (CPA), angular width, linear speed, acceleration, kinetic energy, and other parameters for each CME event. The present work is based on the linear speed and acceleration for each CME that is restricted from 1996 January to 2022 December.

CME speed is considered to be a more prominent parameter when it comes to the impact on space weather (Howard et al. 1985; Cliver et al. 1999; Kane 2010; Kilcik et al. 2020). The linear speed given in the CDAW catalog is fitted by a straight line to the height–time measurements at the fastest section of CMEs (Yashiro et al. 2004; Gopalswamy et al. 2009b). According to the velocity classifications established by Yashiro et al. (2004), we classified them as slow CMEs (V ≤ 250 km s−1), intermediate-speed CMEs (250 km s−1 < V ≤ 450 km s−1), solar-wind-speed CMEs (450 km s−1 < V ≤ 900 km s−1), and fast CMEs (V > 900 km s−1).

The acceleration given in the CDAW was quadratic fitted by the height–time plot (Yashiro et al. 2004; Gopalswamy et al. 2009b). The acceleration of a CME might be positive, negative, or almost zero, which indicates that it will either accelerate, continue to accelerate, or decelerate while inside the LASCO field of view (see the footnote 5). In the circumstances, each CME has an acceleration affecting the linear speed, and we generally mark the accelerating CMEs (the acceleration of a CME is positive) and decelerating CMEs (the acceleration of a CME is negative) for each classification of the linear speed. The daily occurrence of the accelerating and decelerating CMEs for the four classifications of the linear speed varied with time is shown in Figure 1 by the black line. It should be pointed out that the observation gaps from 1998 June 26 to 1998 October 9, and from 1998 December 21 to 1999 February 2 (Gopalswamy et al. 2003a) correspond to the breaks in Figure 1 and the linear speeds of CMEs tagged with “- - - -” are out of consideration. In addition, if there is no CME occurring in a certain day, we count the number of this day as zero. Then, according to the date of the minima and maxima for the past solar cycles given by the website, 6
6
https://www.sidc.be/SILSO/cyclesminmax we divide the time series into solar cycles 23 and 24.

caption.p: The daily distribution of the different classifications of the speed for the accelerating and decelerating CMEs from 1996 January 1 to 2022 December 31. The left column denotes instances of accelerating CMEs while the right column represents decelerating CMEs. The panels show CMEs with slow, intermediate, solar wind, and fast speeds, arranged from top to bottom. The black lines represent all CMEs, and the blue lines represent CMEs that removed the special event.

sec.p: However, according to Yashiro et al. (2004), it is challenging to follow the same leading edge in the image series of a faint CME. Therefore, in order to rate the CME speeds obtained from the height–time measurements properly, they characterized the features of each CME with a quality index: poor, fair, typical, good, and excellent. The quality indices are stored as a numerical value between 1 (poor) and 5 (good) in height–time digital files, and the CME with unclear leading edges is designated with a quality index of zero. On the other hand, the detection rate of the narrow CMEs also needs to be considered carefully (Yashiro et al. 2008). Fortunately, Michalek et al. (2019) give a reasonable definition of such special events (having quality index ≤1 or widths ≤5°); therefore, we exclude special events by the same definition, and the daily occurrence excludes the special events of accelerating and decelerating CMEs for the four classifications of the linear speed varied with time is shown in Figure 1 by the blue lines.

sec.title: Method
sec.p:
Meanwhile, from Figure 1, we can see that the time series seem to have autocorrelated structures, so the nonparametric autocorrelation function in Python library 7
7
https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/generated/statsmodels.graphics.tsaplots.plot_acf.html is employed to investigate the basic information about these time series, and according to the parameters introduction in the library, the 95% confidence band is computed according to Bartlett’s formula for white noise. The results (with the 95% confidence bands for the series) are shown in Figure 2, where we can see that the autocorrelated periodicity pattern of more than 3 yr is out of the range of quasi-biennial oscillations. Thus, the continuous wavelet transformation (CWT), a time-frequency method developed by Torrence & Compo (1998), is used to focus on diagnosing the short periodic signals of the time series. For a better comparison, the same as Li et al. (2023), the two observation gaps of the time series are supplemented with a linear interpolation.

caption.p: The nonparametric autocorrelation function of the different classifications of the speed for the accelerating and decelerating CMEs from 1996 January 1 to 2022 December 31. The left two columns are for all events for the CMEs (the eight subfigures correspond to the black lines in Figure 1) while the right two columns are for the CMEs that have removed the special events (the other eight subfigures correspond to the blue lines in Figure 1).

sec.p:
CWT is usually used to analyze the variation of temporal frequency in a time series of the solar index (Zolotova & Ponyavin 2007; Li et al. 2011, 2023; Ravindra et al. 2021). PyCWT is a model in Python for CWT spectral analysis. 8
8
https://pycwt.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html Here, the PyCWT is applied to investigate the temporal variation of the daily occurrence of the accelerating and decelerating CMEs for four classifications of speed. In this course of the PyCWT application, we adopted the center frequency of the Morlet wavelet function (ω 0) with ω 0 = 6 to satisfy the admissibility condition that the period and the wavelet timescale are nearly equal. We also consider the increase in local power to be significant when the ratio of power over the red noise (α = 0.7) at the 95% confidence level is greater than one. In plots of local wavelet spectra, those regions (power/sig95 > 1) are enclosed by black solid contour lines (Torrence & Compo 1998; Grinsted et al. 2004; Li et al. 2023).

The result of the wavelet analysis for a given data set was only a time-frequency spectrum (the so-called local wavelet spectrum), and it is necessary to distinguish the peaks from the background spectrum of the local wavelet spectrum. Kestin (1998) suggested that the global wavelet spectrum could recognize the peak signals from the background spectrum. Then, it is more important to recognize these peaks as significant periodic signals. According to Gilman (1963), our time series is the red spectrum, which allows for the interdiurnal persistence in the daily rate of CMEs, thus there should be red noise for the global wavelet spectrum. Torrence & Compo (1998) suggest that 95% confidence intervals in the global wavelet spectra could be restricted under certain circumstances, but it is difficult to confidently determine whether a periodic effect is present from the wavelet spectrum of an autocorrelated time series. So, combining the results of Figure 2 with the investigation by Torrence & Compo (1998), we used the 95% confidence level with red noise α = 0.7 for the local and global wavelet spectrum, which has also been suggested as an appropriate confidence level for such time series (Li et al. 2023).

Moreover, not only the 95% confidence level but also the cone of influence (COI) is necessary for the results to be deemed reliable. According to Torrence & Compo (1998), Grinsted et al. (2004), and Li et al. (2023), the crosshatched region in the local wavelet spectrum known as the COI, where the edge effects on time-series analysis cannot be disregarded. Consequently, peak signals within the COI should not be regarded as true signals. More importantly, putative periodicities in time series show up as peaks mingled with other peaks originating from data fluctuations. These fluctuations may be real, i.e., inherent to the underlying physical processes, or noise resulting from errors in the detection of events and the measurements of physical quantities (Barlyaeva et al. 2018). In the following results, same as Lou et al. (2003) and Li et al. (2023), in order to evaluate potential errors in periods (P) of recognized power peaks, we think about half of the full width at half-maximum about a power peak then come to the period variation (ΔP), thus an estimated period variation for an identified power peak can be described as P ± ΔP.

sec.title: The Distribution of Different Speed CMEs
sec.p: As shown in Figure 1, there is a highly distinguishable distribution of the different speed classifications of CMEs. The most obvious thing to see overall is the lowest number of fast CMEs, especially the lowest number of fast accelerated CMEs in solar cycle 24. It appears that the distribution of accelerated (decelerated) CMEs for all speed categories is quite distinctly different between solar cycle 23 and solar cycle 24. From the above, the special events are out of our consideration in the following results, in order to more easily compare the distribution of the CMEs for different speed classifications during cycles 23 and 24. We provided the information in Table 1. CME counts are somewhat misleading because solar cycle lengths differ; for better comparisons, the average CME rates (counts/cycle length) are given following the counts.

caption.p: The Number of the Different Speed Classification for the Accelerating (Decelerating) CMEs

table-wrap-foot.p: Note. The average CME rates (counts/cycle length) are given following the counts.

sec.p: As listed in Table 1, the CME rates of the four speed classifications in cycle 23 are greater than those in cycle 24. That is similar to the solar cycle, that the strength of cycle 24 is weaker than cycle 23 (Michalek et al. 2019). The rates of the slow and intermediate-speed accelerating CMEs are larger than the decelerating for both cycles 23 and 24, while the rates of the solar wind and fast-speed accelerating CMEs are smaller than the decelerating. In particular, the total rate of slow-accelerating CMEs is more (140%) than slow-decelerating CMEs, and the rate of fast-decelerating CMEs is far more (108%) than fast-accelerating CMEs, which is in substantial agreement with Yashiro et al. (2004) who noted that most of fast CMEs exhibit deceleration, while most of slow CMEs exhibit acceleration.

sec.title: Periods of Different Speed CMEs
sec.p: In order to give more details about the different speed classifications of CMEs for accelerating and decelerating dynamical types of CMEs, as shown in Figures 3 and 4, we investigated the periodicity behavior of the four classifications of CMEs for accelerating and decelerating CMEs. For better recognition of the periods of the above four classifications of the CMEs, the significant periodic signal (above the 95% confidence level of red noise) of Figures 3 and 4 are summarized in Table 2.

caption.p: Local wavelet spectra (left column) and global wavelet spectra (right column) of accelerating CMEs. From top to bottom are the ones for CMEs with the velocities of V ≤ 250 km s−1, 250 km s−1 < V ≤ 450 km s−1, 450 km s−1 < V ≤ 900 km s−1, and V > 900 km s−1, respectively. The yellow color bars of the local wavelet power spectrum represent maximum power and the purple represent power. The region in the local wavelet spectra affected by the mother wavelet’s COI is shown by the crosshatched and shaded area, and the red dashed line in the global wavelet spectra corresponds to the 95% confidence level of red noise.
Similar to Figure 3, but for the decelerating CMEs.
The Periods of the Different Speed Classification for Accelerating (Decelerating) CMEs

sec.p: From Table 2, we can see that the periodicity behavior for different speed classifications of CMEs all have the three typical periodic signals: 1.0–7.0 month (mo), 0.60–1.80 yr, and 1.80–2.80 yr. It is known that the Rieger-type period is around 154 days (Rieger et al. 1984), and the quasi-biennial oscillations are between 0.6 and 4 yr (Bazilevskaya et al. 2014). So, it can be concluded that the Rieger-type periods and the quasi-biennial oscillations exist in the different speed classifications of CMEs, and the patterns of these known signals for the fast CMEs are more complex.

Yurchyshyn et al. (2005) found that the speed distributions of accelerating and decelerating CMEs are almost the same and can be roughly fitted by a single lognormal distribution, indicating that there is no physical difference between the accelerating and the decelerating CME, at least not in terms of statistics. That is to say, according to the lognormal distribution of CME speeds, the same nonlinear driving mechanism appears to be at work in both the slow and fast dynamical types of CMEs. However, combining that with our results we can find that the patterns of accelerating CME for solar wind speed CMEs are indeed as simple as the decelerating ones, while for the slow and fast-speed classifications of CMEs, the possible mechanism that drives the accelerating and the decelerating CME are more complicated.

sec.title: Periods of Accelerating and Decelerating CMEs
sec.p: To further illustrate the possible mechanism that drives the accelerating and the decelerating CMEs above, we also investigated the periodic behavior of the accelerating and decelerating CMEs as shown in Figure 5. As we can see, there is a different wavelet power spectrum between accelerating and decelerating CMEs, combining the global wavelet spectra (right column), considering the confidence level (95%) of red noise for the global wavelet spectra, and there are four peaks in the global wavelet spectra of accelerating CMEs, while only the three peaks of decelerating CMEs, and the significant periods are listed in Table 3.

caption.p: Local wavelet spectra (left column) and global wavelet spectra (right column) of accelerating CMEs and decelerating CMEs. The yellow color bars of the local wavelet power spectrum represent maximum power and the purple represent power. The region in the local wavelet spectra affected by the mother wavelet’s COI is shown by the crosshatched and shaded area, and the black dashed lines in the global wavelet spectra correspond to the 95% confidence level of red noise.
The Periods of Accelerating (Decelerating) CMEs and the Ones at Different Speed Classification of CMEs

sec.p: From Table 3, we can quickly see that like the results above, there are two typical periodic behaviors (the Rieger-type periods and the quasi-biennial oscillations) of CMEs. The Rieger-type periods of the accelerating and decelerating CMEs have a similar pattern, and while the pattern of the quasi-biennial oscillations for the accelerating CME is more complex than decelerating ones, what is striking is that it is the same periodic behavior of 2.44 yr for the accelerating and decelerating CMEs. The periodic behaviors of 2.44 yr for both accelerating and decelerating might be similar because of the lognormal distribution for both accelerating and decelerating CMEs (Yurchyshyn et al. 2005). It could be concluded that the dynamics mechanism of accelerating and decelerating CMEs are modulated not only by the mechanism of quasi-biennial oscillations but also by the Rieger-type periods.

sec.title: Periods of CMEs During Solar Cycles 23 and 24
sec.p: From the local wavelet spectra above, we also noticed that the information (period and power) changes with time. Thus, in order to get more detailed wavelet spectra information about the difference between accelerating and decelerating CMEs, we calculated the wavelet power spectrum and the global wavelet spectra of the accelerating CMEs and decelerating CMEs separately for each solar cycle as shown in Figure 6. It shows that there is a very different wavelet power spectrum and the global wavelet spectra of ones between the solar cycle 23 and solar cycle 24. To better give the comparison of the periods of CMEs during the solar cycles 23 and 24, we overview the results in Table 4.

caption.p: Local wavelet spectra (left column) and global wavelet spectra (right column) for accelerating and decelerating CMEs in cycles 23 and 24. The yellow color bars of the local wavelet power spectrum represent maximum power and the purple represent power. The region in the local wavelet spectra affected by the mother wavelet’s COI is shown by the crosshatched and shaded area, and the black dashed lines in the global wavelet spectra correspond to the 95% confidence level of red noise.
The Periods of the CMEs During Solar Cycles 23 and 24

sec.p: From Table 4, it is clear that the two typical periodic signals (Rieger-type periods and quasi-biennial oscillations) mentioned above are diagnosed in cycles 23 and 24. It should be emphasized that these two typical periodic signals exhibit differently between the two cycles.

For the solar cycle 23, Rieger-type periodic values are slightly different between accelerating and decelerating CMEs, while the same values of quasi-biennial oscillations (they are all 1.09 and 2.30 yr) for the CMEs. For the solar cycle 24, there is also a slight difference in the Rieger-type periodic values between accelerating and decelerating CMEs, but the pattern of the quasi-biennial oscillations for the decelerating CMEs is more complex compared to the accelerating CMEs (1.83 yr). Overall, the periodic signals of 1.09 yr only exist in the solar cycle 23. Thus, there are the Rieger-type periods and quasi-biennial oscillations with different values between solar cycles 23 and 24.

It should be noted that there is a time shift between activity in the northern and southern hemispheres, which varies between solar cycles. And also Zhang et al. (2023) suggested the occurrence of CMEs is characterized by the hemispheric asymmetry. To verify this even further, similar to Zhang et al. (2023), we convert the CPAs to heliographic latitudes (Yashiro et al. 2004), and then divided the CMEs into northern (the latitudes range from 0 to 90) and southern (the latitudes range from −90 to 0) hemispheres. The northern results of accelerating CMEs and decelerating CMEs separately for each solar cycle are shown in Figure 7, and the southern ones are shown in Figure 8.

caption.p: Similar to Figure 6, but for the northern hemisphere.
Similar to Figure 6, but for the southern hemisphere.

sec.p: From Figures 7 and 8, we can see that the power value of the local wavelet spectra near the solar activity in the northern hemisphere is different from the southern hemisphere for both cycles 23 and 24. It is reasonable that high-latitude prominences appear (rush-to-the-pole phenomenon) and their eruptions resemble quiescent-region-prominence eruptions. Gopalswamy (2015) suggested that there is hemispheric asymmetry for prominence eruption rates. Prominence eruptions are the most common CME-associated phenomenon (Munro et al. 1979). In addition, Zhang et al. (2024) suggested that there is no rush-to-the-pole phenomenon of the halo CME source locations. Thus, here the time shift between the northern and southern hemispheres for the accelerating CMEs and decelerating CMEs might affected by the rush-to-the-pole phenomenon. For better recognition, we also overview the hemispheric results in Table 5.

caption.p: Similar to Table 4, but for the Hemispheric Periods of the CMEs during Solar Cycles 23 and 24

sec.p: From Table 5, we can see the Rieger-type periods and quasi-biennial oscillations with different values between solar cycles 23 and 24 for the northern and southern hemispheres. For cycle 23, the periodicity patterns of the Rieger-type periods in the southern hemisphere are the most complicated, while periodicity patterns of the quasi-biennial oscillations are relatively simple for both the northern and southern hemispheres. For cycle 24, the periodicity patterns of the Rieger-type periods in the northern hemisphere for decelerating CMEs are more complex compared to the others, while periodicity patterns of the quasi-biennial oscillations for the northern hemisphere are simple compared to the southern hemisphere.

sec.title: Conclusions and Discussion
sec.p:
In this paper, we present a detailed investigation of the periodic behavior of the daily occurrence CMEs, based on the accelerating and decelerating CMEs at four speed classifications. The following conclusion can be drawn from the above.1.
The distribution of CMEs over time is quite distinctly different for different speeds. Furthermore, this difference varies from solar cycle 23 to cycle 24.2.
The different speed CMEs have two types of periodic signals: Rieger-type periods and quasi-biennial oscillations, and there are some variations of the ones for different speed CMEs.3.
The Rieger-type periods and quasi-biennial oscillations of the CMEs are different in solar cycles 23 and 24. And the periodicity patterns for the northern hemisphere are different from the southern hemisphere in solar cycles 23 and 24.

It is recognized that CMEs from different source regions have different speeds (Gosling et al. 1976). Fast CMEs are thought to be associated with active regions (strong magnetic fields) and tend to lag behind sunspot activity (Gopalswamy et al. 2003b, 2010a), whereas slow CMEs are thought to be associated with quiescent-prominence eruptions (weak magnetic fields; Bilenko 2017). The speeds of the filament eruption-associated CMEs were strongly correlated with the average magnetic field in the filament channel, and the CMEs associated with nonactive region filaments had higher eruption speeds than those with active region filaments (Chen et al. 2006). In addition, streamer-blowout CMEs (a particular class of CMEs with lower speeds) arise from extended polarity inversion lines outside active regions (quiet Sun and polar crown filaments; Vourlidas & Webb 2018), so that is reasonable about the different distributions of CMEs at different speeds.

The Rieger-type periods were once considered as the harmonics of the solar rotation period (Bai & Sturrock 1991). Lara et al. (2008) identified the periodic signals at 193, 36, 28, and 25 days of the mean (averaged of about 3 days) numbers of CMEs, and they suggested that CMEs reduce the magnetic flux in a quasiperiodic process in a way similar to that of magnetic flux emergence and other solar eruptive activity. Here, just estimated numerically, the Rieger-type periods are the harmonics of the solar rotation period for the accelerating and decelerating CMEs. But, it is a pity that the power of the rotation periods for the accelerating and decelerating CMEs is below the confidence level. Lou (2000) suggested that the Rieger-type periods could be examined by Rossby and mixed Rossby–Poincaré waves. Bilenko (2014) examined the impact of the solar global magnetic-field structure evolution CME occurrence rate and parameters and demonstrated that CME distribution is affected by evolutionary modifications of the global magnetic-field structure, the fluctuations in the global magnetic-field structure are suggested to be caused by the creation of magnetic Rossby waves in the solar tachocline, and every Rossby wave period gives preference to a specific global magnetic-field structure. Then the variations in wave durations are suggested to cause the global magnetic-field structure reorganization, which, in turn, causes variations in CME position, occurrence rate, and parameters.

Solar flares are a valuable indicator of the periodic signal at 155 ± 5 days (Rieger et al. 1984; Bogart & Bai 1985). The number of C-class flares increased by about 16% during the solar cycle 24 compared to cycle 23 (Kilcik et al. 2020). It should be noted that Choudhary et al. (2014) found a 6 month signal exists in the CME occurrence for cycle 23, but a 5 month signal for cycle 24. Here, it is more reasonable that the periods of the CME in cycle 24 are different from cycle 23.

The quasi-biennial oscillations appear to be a fundamental aspect of solar activity and are of great importance not only for the investigation of the solar dynamo but also in terms of space weather (Bazilevskaya et al. 2014; Anstey et al. 2022). The quasi-biennial oscillations were once evaluated in the monthly CME occurrence by Lamy et al. (2019). Kilcik et al. (2020) examined the temporal variations of the maximum CME speed index and the number of solar X-ray flares of each class, and they discovered that 546 days (1.49 yr) were detected in the maximum CME speed index. Zhang et al. (2001) pointed out that the CMEs display an impulsive acceleration phase that coincides very well with the flares’ rise phase, and the acceleration of CMEs ceases near the peak time of the soft X-ray flares. Here, we have diagnosed the periodic value at 1.45 yr in the fast-accelerating CME, and the slow-decelerating CMEs. That is to say, the flares are closely linked to the CMEs.

Meanwhile, Inceoglu & Loto’aniu (2023) first detected signals in the Earth’s magnetosphere with periods ranging from 1.3 to 1.6 yr, which can be associated with the solar quasi-biennial oscillations using data from multiple Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite missions. And they also found that the z-component of the geomagnetic field B (cross product of the x- and y-component of the geomagnetic field B), exhibits the signals roughly 1.4 yr in solar cycles 22 and 23, while in the solar cycle 24, the larger amplitude variation is significantly weaker than solar cycles 22 and 23, the higher amplitude variation has a period of 2.7 yr, but the one is not seen for the y-component of the geomagnetic field B. That is to say, the quasi-biennial oscillations of the geomagnetic field are different from solar cycles 23 to 24.

Mehta et al. (2022) found a reduced presence of the quasi-biennial oscillations in cycle 24 compared to cycle 23 in the solar interior. The quasi-biennial oscillation signals are present in cycles 23 and 24 with different periodic values (Jain et al. 2023). Michalek et al. (2019) emphasize that the detection rate of the CMEs reported in the SOHO/LASCO database is not only the result of variations in the magnetic structures associated with sunspots but also of the global evolution of the magnetic field on the Sun. The diminished total pressure of the heliosphere in cycle 24 allows CMEs to expand more easily (Gopalswamy et al. 2015).

It should be emphasized that the solar cycle 23 is much stronger than cycle 24 as evidenced by the higher sunspot number. Cycle 23 had more active regions that are associated with more energetic CMEs, than the fast CMEs and the average CME speed is higher than in cycle 24. Vourlidas & Webb (2018) pointed out that during solar cycle 23, the streamer-blowout CMEs are faster and more energetic (shorter duration, higher speed, and kinetic energy) but less frequent toward the maximum, suggesting that some of those streamer-blowouts may be associated with active regions, while no such trend was seen in solar cycle 24. Here, our results show that certain periodic patterns in cycle 23 disappeared in cycle 24, such as 1.09 yr only exists in solar cycle 23.

Gopalswamy et al. (2022) addressed the connection between solar activity and space weather events in solar cycles 23 and 24 and suggested that the diminished heliospheric magnetic field in solar cycle 24 reduces the efficiency of particle acceleration, resulting in fewer high-energy solar energetic particle events. Here, our results show that the periodicity patterns of CMEs during solar cycle 24 are different from the ones of solar cycle 23. Zhang et al. (2023) suggested that there are hemispheric asymmetric features of CMEs, and also Zhang et al. (2024) suggested that there are hemispheric asymmetric features of halo coronal mass ejection source locations. Here, our results show that the periodic patterns of the CMEs in the northern hemisphere are indeed different from the southern hemisphere. During the solar cycle 24, the patterns of the Rieger-type periods in the northern hemisphere are more complex compared to the southern hemisphere, while the patterns of the quasi-biennial oscillations in the southern hemisphere are more complex compared to the northern hemisphere. That is, the diminished heliospheric magnetic field in solar cycle 24 affects different periodic patterns in different hemispheres.

In addition, Gopalswamy et al. (2009a) showed that the CME speeds and widths are correlated with a correlation coefficient (r = 0.69) for solar cycle 23. Also, Gopalswamy et al. (2014) confirmed this correlation and further pointed out that the slopes of the regression lines are remarkably different between solar cycle 23 and 24; the slope of solar cycle 24 is 0.16, which is steeper than the one (0.11) of solar cycle 23, indicating that for a given CME speed, the CME width in the cycle 24 is wider. For solar cycle 24, CMEs expand more rapidly early on and appear to surround the occulting disk (Gopalswamy et al. 2010b). Here, our results show that the four CME speed classifications all have two typical signals of Rieger-type periods and quasi-biennial oscillations. The two types of periodic signals are once found in the different CME widths, and the periodicity patterns for the northern hemisphere are different from the southern hemisphere in solar cycles 23 and 24 for the different angular widths (Li et al. 2023).

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We sincerely acknowledge the reviewers for the insightful comments. We would like to sincerely thank everyone who has contributed to the publicly available data on the websites. NASA, The Catholic University of America, and the Naval Research Laboratory collaborate to create and maintain this CME catalog at the CDAW Data Center. SOHO is a project of international cooperation between ESA and NASA.

Our work is supported by the National SKA Program of China No. 2020SKA0110300, the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 12373097), Guangzhou Science, Technology Funds (No. 2023A03J0016) and the Major Key Project of Peng Cheng Laboratory, Basic and Applied Basic Research Foundation Project of Guangdong Province (No. 2024A1515011503), the “Yunnan Revitalization Talent Support Program” Innovation Team Project, the Yunnan Fundamental Research Projects (grant No. 202301AV070007).
